column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.
Non-vaccinated travelers from Latvia, Luxembourg, Romania must present COVID-19 test and quarantine for 10 days; list of 'red' countries updated.
All travellers entering this country must complete the Passenger's Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival. Travellers must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:
Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and AstraZeneca.
Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
Negative test (within 72 hours) or antigen test (within 48 hours).

Every traveller arriving in Lithuania will have to fill in a form on the website of the National Public Health Centre within 48 hours before entering Lithuania and present the confirmation received, the QR code, at the time of boarding or at at the border control.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- travellers from some countries face stricter measures.
Non-vaccinated travelers from Latvia, Luxembourg, Romania must present COVID-19 test and quarantine for 10 days; list of 'red' countries updated.
Entering this country with the EU Digital COVID certificate. EUDCCs are valid to enter Lithuania if they contain one of the following: a certificate of vaccination; a certificate of recovery from COVID-19, confirmed by a positive PCR test, valid for 180 days since the date of the positive test; a pre-departure negative COVID-19 test. Accepted tests: PCR taken within 72 hours prior to arrival or rapid antigen test (RAT) taken within 48 hours prior to arrival.
Passengers arriving from red, grey and black countries/areas must self-isolate for 10 days and follow mandatory isolation regulations.
Passnegers from red or grey countries/areas, if they are vaccinated or recovered, need not comply with testing and self-isolation requirements.
Passengers arriving from orange and green countries do not have to self-isolate.
Passengers arriving from black countries/areas, even if they are vaccinated or recovered, must self-isolate until they produce a negative test result.
All third countries are classified as "grey" countries and listed as risk areas. Travellers from third countries must present one of the following: a certificate of vaccination; a certificate of recovery from Covid-19, confirmed by a positive PCR test, valid for 180 days since the date of the positive test; a pre-departure negative Covid-19 test. Accepted tests: PCR taken within 72 hours prior to arrival or RAT (rapid antigen test) taken within 48 hours prior to arrival.
column4:
The EU Digital COVID Certificate (available as of 1 July 2021) provides proof that a person has either:
been vaccinated against COVID-19 (vaccine type and manufacturer, number of doses, date of vaccination);
received a negative test result, PCR or rapid antigen, with the name of the test, date and time of test, test centre and result (self-tests are not valid);
recovered from COVID-19 (positive PCR test result valid for 180 days).
When travelling, holders of the EU Digital COVID Certificate will have the same rights as citizens of the visited Member State who have been vaccinated, tested or recovered.

Travellers who have been fully vaccinated for COVID-19 are exempted from providing a negative COVID-19 test. A certificate of vaccination is needed.
Accepted vaccines: Janssen, Comirnaty (Pfizer/BioNTech), Moderna and Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca)
column5:
Latest News: Lithuanian authorities tighten entry rules for arrivals from Romania from 27 December (Schengen Visa Info, 24.12.2021). Lithuanian authorities will ease entry restrictions for travelers from Fuerteventura, Gran Canaria, Tenerife and French Guiana from 13 December (SVI, 11.12.2021).

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU:

All travellers entering this country must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

Travellers must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:

  • Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and AstraZeneca.
  • Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
  • Negative test (within 72 hours) or antigen test (within 48 hours).

Entry requirements depend on the colour attributed to the country of departure, according to Lithuania's national classification of risk areas:

  • Passengers arriving from red, grey and black countries/areas must self-isolate for 10 days and follow mandatory isolation regulations.
  • Passengers from red or grey countries/areas, if they are vaccinated or recovered, need not comply with testing and self-isolation requirements.
  • Passengers arriving from orange and green countries do not have to self-isolate.
  • Passengers arriving from black countries/areas, even if they are vaccinated or recovered, must self-isolate until they produce a negative test result.

Learn More:

Travel Portal

City of Vilnius


Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays

*Transit:

Travellers in transit must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

Transit is allowed for citizens of non-EU/Schengen area countries: 

- On their return to their country of residence;

- In whose respect a reasoned request has been made by a foreign country;

- Via the territory of the Russian Federation to Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation and backward (via Kena railway border checkpoint and Kybartai railway border checkpoint).

Learn More:

Travel Portal

City of Vilnius



*From Third Countries:

Travel to Lithuania from non-EU/Schengen countries is restricted to those who are fully vaccinated (14 days after taking the final dose of treatment) or who qualify for special exemptions.

Travellers must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

They must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:

  • Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and AstraZeneca.
  • Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
  • Negative test (within 72 hours) or antigen test (within 48 hours).

Entry requirements depend on the colour attributed to the country of departure, according to Lithuania's national classification of risk areas:

  • Passengers arriving from red, grey and black countries/areas must self-isolate for 10 days and follow mandatory isolation regulations.
  • Passengers from red or grey countries/areas, if they are vaccinated or recovered, need not comply with testing and self-isolation requirements.
  • Passengers arriving from orange and green countries do not have to self-isolate.
  • Passengers arriving from black countries/areas, even if they are vaccinated or recovered, must self-isolate until they produce a negative test result.

National Public Health Center



*From Third Countries:

Travel to Lithuania from non-EU/Schengen countries is restricted to those who are fully vaccinated (14 days after taking the final dose of treatment) or who qualify for special exemptions.

Travellers must complete the Passenger's Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

They must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:

  • Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and AstraZeneca.
  • Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
  • Negative test (within 72 hours) or antigen test (within 48 hours).

Entry requirements depend on the colour attributed to the country of departure, according to Lithuania's national classification of risk areas:

  • Passengers arriving from red, grey and black countries/areas must self-isolate for 10 days and follow mandatory isolation regulations.
  • Passengers from red or grey countries/areas, if they are vaccinated or recovered, need not comply with testing and self-isolation requirements.
  • Passengers arriving from orange and green countries do not have to self-isolate.
  • Passengers arriving from black countries/areas, even if they are vaccinated or recovered, must self-isolate until they produce a negative test result.

Travel Portal

National Public Health Center



Internal Restrictions:
*Facemasks: You must wear a medical facemask in all indoor public spaces in Lithuania, including shops, restaurants, businesses, workplaces, museums, theatres, public transport, taxis and educational environments.
Masks should be three layers of non-woven material and bear the CE marking on their packaging.
This does not apply to children under the age of six, or people with a medical exemption. If you cannot wear facemasks on medical grounds, you are advised to wear face shields if possible. Exemptions also apply to those doing physical exercise, providing a service that cannot be done with a facemask, or consuming food or drink.
*Public places and services: A number of restrictions apply to those not vaccinated against COVID-19. Foreign residents in Lithuania may be able to apply for the Lithuanian Freedom Pass, to prove their vaccination status. More information about registering for the pass is available on the Lithuanian Ministry of the Economy and Innovation website. The pass is designed to be used for public services in Lithuania, it is not considered valid proof of vaccination status for the purpose of international travel.
From 1 December, the requirements for Freedom Passes for those aged 16 and over will change. To access the Freedom Pass/services previously available to those with a Freedom Pass, you will need to have proof of the following:
• Confirmation that you completed a full course of a COVID-19 vaccine approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) within the last 7 months; or
• Confirmation that you have had an EMA approved COVID-19 vaccine booster within the last 7 months; or
• A negative COVID-19 PCR test result, taken within the last 72 hours. PCR tests for individuals aged 16 and over, for the purpose of a Freedom Pass, will be charged; or
• Proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the last 7 months.
From 28 December, the requirement for a Freedom Pass or equivalent to access most non-essential public services in Lithuania will be extended to children aged 12 and over. Children aged over 12, but under 16, will be required to show:
• Confirmation that they completed a full course of EMA approved COVID-19 vaccine within the last 7 months. Full vaccination for children is considered to be two doses of vaccine; or
• A negative COVID-19 PCR test result, taken within the last 72 hours. Tests for children under 16 are available free of charge.
• Proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the last 7 months.
Lithuania will request proof of vaccination. If you are travelling with a printed PDF proof of vaccination status, it must date from 1 November to ensure that the certificate can be scanned successfully, if domestic certification is required.
More information on COVID-19 related restrictions to public places and services in Lithuania is available on the KoronaStop website.
